Socialist Republic of Viet Nam 
 
The  proposal  comprises  a  proposed  loan  of  $35  million  for 
subprogram II of the Second Financial Sector Program Loan (FSPL 
II).  FSPL  II  takes  a  cluster  approach  and  consists  of  two  back-to-
back  subprograms.  Implementation  of  FSPL  II—subprogram  I  is 
scheduled for completion in December 2004.

Viet  Nam’s  financial  sector  mirrors  its  economy  and  is  in  transition. 
The  Government  has  made  persistent  efforts  to  modernize  and 
transform  the  financial  sector,  recognizing  its  significance  to  the 
country’s  economic  performance.  Still,  plagued  by  many  factors 
inherited from the former regime, the formal financial system remains 
underdeveloped, inefficient, and inaccessible to many. 
 
Financial  intermediation  is  low,  and  is  dominated  by  bank  savings

 Risks and Safeguards 

v 

FSPL  II  faces  three  principal  risks.  The  first  is  the  resurfacing  of 
sociopolitical  pressure  that  could  delay  reform.  Materialization  of 
this risk is contingent on economic performance. Judging from the 
current  status  of  the  economy  and  its  outlook—as  well  as  pro-
reform  statements  and  achievements  made  by  the  Government 
with full public support—this risk is currently limited. Nevertheless, 
macroeconomic  conditions  and  the  sociopolitical  situation  will  be 
closely monitored against program objectives. 
 
The  second  risk  relates  to  progress  in  restructuring  state-owned 
banks and state-owned enterprises (SOEs), both of which weigh 
heavily on Viet Nam’s financial sector. Many technical difficulties 
remain, and slower-than-expected progress has had implications 
on achieving the objectives of FSPL II. However, the momentum 
building  toward  carrying  out  the  reform  process  is  strong  within 
the  Government.  The  comprehensive  frameworks  that  the  World 
Bank  developed  under  the  PRSC  for  restructuring  banks  and 
SOEs,  as  well  as  associated  technical  assistance  from  bilateral 
agencies,  will  provide  the  necessary  technical  support.  ADB's 
close coordination with IMF and the World Bank will continue, in 
order  to  synchronize  the  subsectoral  reform  measures  and 
achieve the full benefits of FSPL II.  
 
The third risk pertains to the technical capacities of implementing 
agencies.  The  Government’s  track  record  suggests  that,  given 
adequate  technical  support,  its  commitment  to  undertake  the 
proposed  reforms  is  strong.  In  implementing  subprogram  I,  for 
example, delays were predominantly a result of a lack of technical 
expertise  in  the  financial  sector,  particularly  for  drafting  laws, 
rules,  and  regulations.  The  delays  were  exacerbated  by  the 
consensus building approach taken for their enactment, requiring 
interministerial  coordination.  To  reduce  this  risk,  comprehensive 
discussions were undertaken with the implementing agencies and 
the  ongoing  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  capacity  building  will 
tackle  the  technical  difficulties  anticipated  with  implementing  the 
policy actions proposed under FSPL II. 

  

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for subprogram II of the Financial Sector Program Loan II 
(FSPL II). 
 

II. 

BACKGROUND 

On 20 November 2002, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Board approved FSPL II,1 
2. 
(i)  the  cluster  concept  of  3  subprograms  for  $75  million,  and  (ii)  subprogram  I  for  $50  million 
from the Asian Development Fund (ADF) to be released in two tranches: one of $20 million and 
one of $30 million. The program’s objective is to support the Government’s efforts in building an 
enabling  environment  for  alternative  channels  of  market-based  financial  intermediation. 
Alternative  financial  intermediation  is  becoming  increasingly  important  for  Viet  Nam,  whose 
financial sector remains dominated by bank savings and loans. The banking sector alone, with 
its high-level of nonperforming loans and planned restructuring, cannot support the economy in 
achieving  its  potential  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  growth,  nor  can  it  generate  employment 
for  the  expanding  labor  force.  Necessary  components  for  an  enabling  environment  include  (i) 
economic  policies  conducive  to  sound  and  vibrant  financial  sector  development;  (ii)  legal  and 
regulatory  frameworks  that  will  promote  innovation  and  healthy  competition  while  monitoring 
and  reducing  systemic  risks,  (iii)  regulators  with  the  authority,  budget,  skills,  and  established 
procedures to monitor and enforce regulations, and (iv) support for financial infrastructure.  
 
3. 
To achieve these objectives, FSPL II focuses on (i) establishing a regulatory framework 
for  the  insurance  industry,  strengthening  the  supervisory  and  regulatory  frameworks  and 
promoting the development of key professionals; (ii) promoting the leasing industry by creating a 
coherent  regulatory  framework,  establishing  ground  rules  for  contract  enforcement,  and 
enhancing  public  awareness;  (iii)  enabling  interbank  and  money  market  development  by 
gradually deregulating interest rates, increasing the number of money market instruments, and 
developing the market microstructure; (iv) fostering capital market financial intermediation by (a) 
establishing  incentives  compatible  with  the  regulatory  framework  for  increasing  the  number  of 
quality shares on the market, (b) strengthening market surveillance, and (c) building the basis 
for participation by institutional investors; and (v) continuing to build financial infrastructure such 
as accounting and auditing systems, secured transactions system, a deposit insurance system, 
and  an  anti-money-laundering  regime.  (The  logical  framework  is  in  Appendix  1  and  summary 
poverty reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 2.) 
 
4. 
Subprogram I was envisioned to be completed within 15 months from loan effectiveness. 
Subprograms  II  and  III  were  to  be  processed  sequentially  upon  completion  of  the  previous 
subprogram and completed within 12 months from effectiveness of each proceeding loan. The 
cluster  approach  provides  the  opportunity  to  refine  proposed  policy  actions  of  succeeding 
subprograms  in  order  to  reflect  the  Government's  achievements,  the  changing  policy 
environment,  and  lessons  learned  from  the  previous  subprogram.  The  program  cluster 
approach thus allows flexibility and gives leverage to implement reform measures in a dynamic 
political, economic, and financial environment. 
 
5. 
FSPL II loan agreement for subprogram I was signed on 29 January 2003. An inception 
mission was fielded from 17 to 18 February 2003. The Government submitted the legal opinion

III. 

MACROECONOMIC DEVELOPMENTS 

7. 
Viet Nam's annual economic growth rate increased from 5.8% in 2001 to 6.4% in 2002, 
and 7.1% in 2003. Growth in the industrial and construction sector was 8.9% in 2002 and 9.6% 
in 2003. Faster-paced economic growth has caused inflation to rise. The consumer price index 
(CPI) rose from 0.8% in 2001 to an average of 3-4% in 2002 and 2003. Against the backdrop of 
robust GDP growth, fiscal and trade deficits increased, with the budget deficit widening to 4.8% 
of  GDP  in  2003  from  3.8%  in  2002.  The  current  account  deficit  rose  to  5.8%  of  GDP  in  2003 
from  2.8%  in  2002.  The  overall  macroeconomic  situation  is  stable,  however,  and  the  fiscal 
deficit sustainable. Stable macroeconomic conditions for the past 2 years, a key precondition for 
implementing financial sector reforms, has supported FSPL II implementation. 
 
The economic targets set by the National Assembly in November 2003—GDP growth of 
8. 
7.5–7.8%, a CPI increase of less than 5%, and fiscal deficit below 5% of GDP—are generally 
viewed  by  the  Government  and  the  donor  community  as  achievable.  The  macroeconomic 
environment carries no immediate risks to FSPL II implementation. However, the relatively low 
level of financial intermediation continues and the nonbanking sector—specifically the insurance 
sector  and  the  capital  markets,  the  two  main  components  of  FSPL  II—have  gained  their 
relevance as important means of domestic savings mobilization. 
 
 Viet Nam is making steady progress in structural reforms. The package of tax reforms 
9. 
was approved by the National Assembly in May 2003 and has become effective as of January 
2004. The number of value-added taxes and exemptions has been reduced and the corporate 
tax  rates  unified  for  domestic  and  foreign-owned  enterprises.  Progress  is  also  seen  in  Viet 
Nam's  commitments  toward  international  integration,  including  the  bilateral  trade  agreement 
with the United States effective December 2001 and the ASEAN Free Trade Area (AFTA) tariff 
reductions,  which  are  proceeding  as  scheduled.  Viet  Nam  also  plans  to  join  the  World  Trade 
Organization (WTO) in 2005. On the other hand, implementation of critical reforms planned for 
large  state-owned  enterprises  (SOEs)  and  the  four  major  state-owned  commercial  banks 
(SOCBs) have been slower than expected, with implications for the money and capital market 
components  of  FSPL  II.  Accelerating  privatization  and  listing  of  large  SOEs  would  bring  the 
much-needed  increase  in  supply  of  securities  to  the  Ho  Chi  Minh  Securities  Trading  Center 
(STC).  Stronger  pressure  on  SOCBs  to  improve  profitability  would  also  encourage  more 
transactions on the secondary money market.

IV. 

FSPL II SUBPROGRAM I—STATUS OF IMPLEMENTATION 

A. 

Status of Subprogram I Second Tranche Release Policy Actions  

In  line  with  the  objectives  of  FSPL  II,  the  Government  adopted  legal,  policy,  and 
10. 
institutional measures under subprogram I. Many measures required extensive coordination to 
ascertain stakeholders' understanding, acceptance, and actual adoption. Of the 17 subprogram 
I  second  tranche  release  conditions,  15  have  been  fully  complied  with  and  2  substantially 
complied with (Appendix 3).  
 
11. 
The  insurance  component  under  subprogram  I  had  seven  second  tranche  release 
conditions,  three  of  which  are  in  support  of  creating  equal  opportunities  to  enhance 
competitiveness of the insurance market. 
 

(i) 

The Ministry of Finance to adopt a simple and transparent approval system 
for changes in the operation of insurance companies (complied with). 

 
12. 
The revised Circular 71, issued by the Ministry of Finance (MOF) as Circular 98 on 15 
October  2004,  streamlines  the  approval  system  for  changes  in  the  operation  of  insurance 
companies, opening of new branches, and introduction of new products, reducing considerably 
the time and steps required for obtaining MOF clearance. 

(ii) 

The Ministry of Finance to continue to grant licenses for insurance brokers, 
regardless  of  the  ownership  form,  to  enhance  competitiveness  in  the 
brokerage business (complied with). 

 
13. 
The number of licensed insurance brokers rose from one state-owned company in 2001 
to five, including one foreign-owned company and several joint-stock companies, by the end of 
September 2004. 

 

 

(iii) 

The  Ministry  of  Finance  to  specify  incentive  measures  for  insurance 
companies  to  develop  new  insurance  products,  especially  for  products  in 
support  of  agricultural,  forestry,  and  fisheries  activities  (substantially 
complied with). 

 
14.  MOF awarded additional incentives to promote industry segments that have experienced 
substantial  losses  for  insurers  and  led  to  withdrawal  of  insurance  products.  To  develop 
agricultural insurance, for example, MOF licensed Groupama, a French insurance company, to 
establish a 100%-foreign-owned, non-life insurance company and gave it preferential treatments 
in  terms  of  agents'  commissions  and  operational  scope.  General  guidelines  on  incentives  will 
need to be prepared in future. Such guidelines, however, will require rigorous actuarial studies 
and cost/benefit analyses. 
 
15. 
supervision and prudential regulations of the insurance sector.

companies (complied with). 

17.  MOF  revised  Circular  72,  providing  regulations  on  financial  issues  of  insurance 
enterprise and insurance brokerage enterprise, and issued it as Circular 99 on 15 October 2004, 
aligning  the  accounting  principles  for  insurance  companies  to  international  practice.  The 
previously  adopted  accounting  system  for  calculating  reserves  of  unearned  premiums, 
outstanding  claims,  and 
incurred-but-not-reported  claims  was  particularly  problematic. 
Reserving  for  non-life  insurers,  for  example,  following  the  pure  statistical  methods,  resulted  in 
overstatements  of  profits  and  commensurate  understatement  of  liabilities,  and  policyholder 
reserves in particular. 

 

 

(vi) 

The  Ministry  of  Finance  to  introduce  detailed  sanction  mechanisms  for 
administrative violations in insurance businesses (complied with). 

 
18. 
Decree  118/2003/ND-CP  on  sanctioning  of  administrative  offences  by  insurance 
companies  was  issued  on  13  October  2003.  Measures  stipulated  under  the  decree  tighten 
enforcement of sanctions for administrative offences in the management and usage of licenses, 
assignment  of  insurance  contracts,  unlawful  competitive  action,  forced  purchase  of  insurance, 
breaches  in  provisions  on  reserve  requirements,  appropriation,  management  and  usage  of 
operational reserves, investment of capital, and financial prudence.

B. 

Program Implementation  

1. 

Insurance and Leasing Sectors 

 

a.  

Insurance Sector 

39. 
FSPL  II  supports  development  of  the  nonbanking  subsector,  represented  by  insurance 
and leasing, both of which are at the early stages of development. While the two industries are 
small, their growth has been exceptional. During subprogram I implementation, steady progress 
was  made  in  putting  in  place  the  necessary  legal  and  regulatory  frameworks  for  building  an 
environment to support the sound development of insurance and leasing. 
 
 
 
40. 
FSPL II aims to promote the sound development of the insurance sector by supporting 
the  Government  in  (i)  creating  a  competitive  business  environment,  (ii)  enhancing  corporate 
governance of insurance companies, (iii) strengthening supervision and prudential regulations, 
and  (iv)  developing  insurance  sector  infrastructure.  The  Government,  as  a  first  step  toward 
meeting these objectives, upgraded the insurance management division to department status in 
August 2003 and strengthened its supervisory capacity. MOF also hosted the 6th Association of 
Southeast  Asian  Nations  (ASEAN)  Insurance  Regulators’  Meeting  and  the  ASEAN  Council  of 
Insurance Meeting from 19 to 23 August 2003. The meeting had more than 80 participants and 
concluded  with  an  agreement  on  concrete  measures  for  cooperation  among  insurance 
supervisors.  Viet  Nam,  as  the  host  country,  presented  thematic  reports  on  the  liberalization 
process of financial services in ASEAN countries and the initial results of opening up Viet Nam’s 
insurance market to foreign companies. 
 

 8 

 

 

b. 

Leasing Sector 

During  implementation  of  FSPL  II—subprogram  I,  several  deregulatory  measures  were 
41. 
adopted to create a competitive environment for financial services (paras. 11-14), strengthening 
supervision  and  prudential  regulations  (paras.  15-18)  and  developing  insurance  sector 
infrastructure (paras. 19-20).  
 
42. 
Recent  achievements  for  improving  corporate  governance  in  the  insurance  sector 
include  Decision  175/2003/QD-TTg  issued  by  the  prime  minister  approving  the  2003-2010 
insurance market development strategy. The strategy addresses, in a phased manner, some of 
the  major  corporate  governance  issues  in  the  insurance  sector.  The  ownership  and 
management of the state-owned insurance companies were reviewed and Bao Viet, the largest 
state-owned  insurance  company,  will  be  transformed  into  a  one-member  limited  liability 
company  operating  under  the  Enterprise  Law.  In  accordance  with  the  strategy,  the  prime 
minister  endorsed  equitization  of  two  other  state-owned  insurers:  HCMC  Insurance  Company 
(Bao  Minh)  and  Vietnam  Reinsurance  Company  (VINARE).  In  July  2004,  Bao  Minh  issued 
shares  worth  D97  billion  or  32%  of  its  equity  to  the  public  while  VINARE  is  planned  for 
equitization and listing on the Ho Chi Minh City STC by 2007. Although the majority stake will 
remain with the state, concrete steps forward have been made toward privatization of the state-
owned insurance companies. 
 
 
 
43. 
To  support  the  emergent  leasing  sector,  FSPL  II  addresses  two  critical  issues:  (i)  the 
regulatory environment is not conducive to business development, and lacks clear ground rules 
for contract enforcement; and (ii) public awareness of the leasing industry is inadequate. With 
SBV’s  solid  commitment  to  developing  the  sector,  progress  was  made  not  only  in  adopting 
measures to fulfill FSPL II policy actions but also to enhance the operating environment for the 
sector.  
 
A second tranche release policy action under subprogram I, requiring consultation with 
44. 
various government ministries and agencies, was fulfilled by October 2003 (paras. 21-22). The 
Government  has  taken  actions  to  improve  the  environment  for  business  development.  These 
include  (i)  issuance  of  a  new  regulation  facilitating  the  opening  of  new  branches,  and  (ii) 
streamlined tax system for financial leases under Circular 24 issued by MOF on 20 March 2003. 
SBV is also revising the decree and circular on leasing and is scheduled to submit them to the 
Government in early 2005. The revised decree will contain provisions on methods to deal with 
leased assets in cases of default on lease contracts (policy action subprogram III, B. 1). SBV, 
MOJ, and the Peoples' Supreme Court are involved in discussions on regulations, procedures, 
and methods to deal with leased assets in the case of default.  
 
45. 
To promote public awareness of leasing, as well as capacity building for those engaged 
in leasing, conferences with leasing professionals from other developing countries were held in 
Hanoi and HCMC on 25 and 27 August 2004, respectively. The conferences were successful in 
promoting better public awareness of leasing, as well as in demonstrating SBV's commitment to 
developing the sector. 
 

2. 

Money and Capital Markets 

46. 
FSPL  II  also  supports  development  of  the  money  and  capital  markets.  The  overall 
development  of  the  two  markets  was  constrained  by  slower-than-expected  progress  in  SOCB 
and  SOE  restructuring.  Nevertheless,  steady  progress  was  made  during  subprogram  I  in 

  

 

9 

 

a. 

Interbank and Money Market 

implementing the necessary legal and regulatory frameworks for expanding the role of the two 
markets within the financial sector. 
 
 
 
47. 
FSPL  II  supports  the  Government's  initiative  to  develop  the  interbank  and  money 
markets by focusing on (i) deregulating interest rates, (ii) developing money market instruments, 
(iii)  improving  the  market  structure,  and  (iv)  enhancing  the  treasury  function  and  capacity  of 
SOCBs.  Availability  of  money  market  instruments  has  increased  as  a  result  of  a  regulation 
allowing the issuance of negotiable certificates of deposit (a first tranche release condition under 
subprogram  I),  regularized  issuance  of  short-term  treasury  bills  by  MOF  and  issuance  of 
regulations on repurchase agreements (second tranche release conditions under subprogram I, 
paras. 23-25). 
 
48. 
To further develop money market instruments, FSPL II also supports an integrated legal 
framework  that  will  allow  for  growth  and  innovation,  and  proposes  adoption  of  a  negotiable 
instruments  law  (policy  actions  subprogram  II,  C.  2,  and  subprogram  III,  C.  1).  With  technical 
inputs  from  ADB  consultants  engaged  under  TA4035-VIE,  the  first  draft  of  the  negotiable 
instruments  law  was  completed  and  the  draft  is  currently  under  review  by  the  steering 
committee  that  was  established  on  2  April  2004  for  that  purpose.  The  committee  comprises 
representatives from SBV, MOF, the Ministry of Planning and Investment (MPI), MOJ, and the 
Government's  Office.  The  draft  law  is  scheduled  for  submission  to  the  National  Assembly  for 
deliberation  in  2006.  Progress  outside  of  FSPL  II  includes  successful  completion  of  the  first 
phase of a World-Bank-funded project on modernizing the banking and payment systems. The 
system  created  the  foundation  for  a  national  payment  system,  integral  for  development  of  the 
interbank and money markets. 
 

b. 

Capital Market 

49. 
Development  objectives  for  the  capital  market  component  of  FSPL  II  include  (i) 
broadening  the  capital  market  base,  (ii)  establishing  a  consolidated  regulatory  framework  and 
market surveillance system (paras. 28-31, and 90), (iii) developing institutional investors (paras. 
31  and  71),  (iv)  developing  self-regulatory  organizations  (para.  72),  and  (v)  enhancing  market 
microstructure. Solid steps forward were taken in all five areas during FSPL II—subprogram I.  
 
50. 
In order to broaden the capital market base, FSPL II supports measures to link the SOE 
equitization program and STC listing through adoption of a list of SOEs as candidates for listing 
(policy action subprogram II, D. 1). In 2003 the Steering Committee on Enterprise Reform and 
Development (SCERD) prepared a list of 2,000 SOEs to be equitized during the next 3 years. 
The  Government  approved  the  list  at  the  end  of  2003.  Among  those  listed,  230  SOEs  have 
been identified as having chartered capital above D10 billion, thus meeting one qualification for 
listing.  Furthermore,  MOF  is  revising  Decree  64  on  equitization,  providing  tax  incentives  for 
listing to SOEs undergoing equitization.  
 
FSPL II also supports a trading board for small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) 
51. 
to  further  broaden  the  capital  market  (policy  action  subprogram  II,  D.  2).  The  prime  minister 
gave approval to open the Hanoi STC for SMEs in 2002. Subsequently, SSC Chairman issued 
Decision  329/QD-UBCK  on  17  December  2003  on  the  functions,  duties,  powers,  and 
organization of the Hanoi STC and on 17 June 2004, MOF approved implementing guidelines 
for the operation of the Hanoi STC. Candidates for listing will have registered capital of D5-30 

 10 

 

billion. The official opening of the Hanoi STC is scheduled for 2005 and as of September 2004 
approximately 10 companies have been identified for listing.3  
 
52.  Measures  taken  to  enhance  market  structure  during  subprogram  I  implementation 
include progress in establishing a centralized depository and an automated clearing/settlement 
system.  In  April  2004,  the  SSC  finalized  an  Information  Technology  (IT)  Master  Plan,  which 
includes  the  depository  and  clearing/settlement  systems.  The  IT  Master  Plan  also  includes  an 
automated surveillance system as well as a circuit breaker system based on market index. Full 
implementation of the IT system is scheduled for 2007. 
 

3. 

Financial Infrastructure 

FSPL  II  includes  four  components  under  financial  infrastructure  development  (i) 
53. 
strengthening  the  accounting  and  auditing  system,  (ii)  implementing  the  registry  for  secured 
transactions  system,  (iii)  strengthening  the  deposit  insurance  system,  and  (iv)  developing  the 
anti-money-laundering regime. 
 

a. 

Accounting and Auditing System 

54. 
The  accounting  and  auditing  system  is  widely  recognized  as  the  key  financial 
infrastructure,  largely  determining  the  soundness  and  efficiency  of  a  market-based  financial 
system. This component of FSPL II seeks to (i) establish accounting enforcement mechanisms, 
and  (ii)  develop  a  competitive  accounting  industry.  The  Accounting  Law  passed  on  17  June 
2003 and Decrees 128 and 129 issued on 31 May 2004, providing guidelines on the Accounting 
Law, brings accounting practices significantly closer to international standards. Decree 105 on 
Independent Audit,4 issued on 30 March 2004, stipulates that all banks, insurance companies, 
listed firms, SOEs, foreign invested enterprises, and nationally important Group A projects must 
be audited by independent auditors who are fully liable for their work. Furthermore, the decree 
bans establishment of any new state-owned auditing companies and requires all currently state-
owned auditing companies and joint stock companies operating under the Enterprise Law to be 
converted  into  partnerships,  private  firms,  or  foreign-invested  companies.  The  decree  became 
effective on 14 April 2004. 
 

b. 

Secured Transactions System 

The  Government  has  made  steady  progress 

55. 
toward  developing  a  nationwide, 
computerized  secured  transactions  registration  system.  In  2002,  registration  centers  for  asset 
transactions were established in Hanoi and HCMC. MOJ is preparing to open a Danang office 
by end 2004. During 10 months of operations in 2003, the Hanoi registration center had 6,043 
applications  to  register  assets,  and  HCMC  had  6,047  applications.  In  the  6  months  starting 
January 2004, the two centers had 4,674 and 4,423 applications, respectively. Some procedural 
issues  need  to  be  addressed,  but  pilot  testing  at  the  two  registration  centers  has  been 
successful.  A  feasibility  study  of  the  nationwide  computerized  registration  system  was 
completed  and  submitted  to  the  Minister  of  Justice  in  July  2004.  Following  approval  of  the 
feasibility  study,  building  a  networked,  and  computerized,  nationwide  secured  transactions 
registration system will begin in 2005.

For the system to function smoothly, interministerial coordination needs to improve. The 
56. 
prime  minister  issued  Directive  21-2003-CT-TTG  on  2  October  2004  to  direct  government 
ministries  and  agencies  involved  in  registration  of  secured  transactions  to  resolve  several 
pending  issues.  Included  are  (i)  Ministry  of  Natural  Resources  and  Environment  on  secured 
transactions for register of immovable properties, (ii) Ministry of Transport and Communication 
for  registration  of  aircraft  and  ships  for  secured  transactions,  (iii)  Ministry  of  Interior  for  the 
position of registrar at the registration offices, and (iv) SBV on compliance by credit institutions 
when  providing  loans  secured  by  registered  assets.  The  drafting  of  the  ordinance  for  secured 
transactions—submission  of  which  to  the  National  Assembly  is  a  FSPL  II  policy  action 
(subprogram III, E-2. 2)—has begun. The ordinance will contain all procedural matters related to 
secured  transactions,  while  the  civil  code,  currently  being  revised,  will  cover  all  substantive 
matters.  The  third  draft  of  the  ordinance  was  produced  and  consultations  with  stakeholders 
begun  during  subprogram  I.  The  National  Assembly’s  deliberation  on  the  ordinance,  however, 
has been delayed to 2005 due to the full legislative schedule of the National Assembly. 
 

c. 

Deposit Insurance System 

57. 
DIV officially became operational in July 2000 under Decision 218 QD/TTg issued by the 
Prime  Minister  on  9  November  1999.  DIV  has  the  mandate  to  (i)  protect  the  legal  interest  of 
small depositors, (ii) contribute to maintaining the stability of credit institutions, and (iii) ensure 
the  safe  and  sound  development  of  the  banking  business.  As  of  May  2004,  DIV  had  paid  out 
D14,067 billion to 1,353 depositors of 32 failed people's credit funds.  
 
58. 
Policy  actions  supported  under  FSPL  II  include  measures  to  (i)  address  moral  hazard 
problems  by  specifying  strict  conditions  under  which  DIV  can  provide  financial  support  to 
problem  banks  (policy  action  subprogram  II,  E-3.  8),  and  (ii)  legally  empower  DIV  to  finance 
from  outside  sources  the  payout  for  depositors  in  cases  of  large  failures  and  charge  different 
premiums in accordance to distinct categories of credit institutions being covered (policy action 
subprogram II, E-3. 7). DIV management reviewed its operations 3 years after establishment in 
2004  and  identified  eleven  policy  changes  needed,  including  policy  actions  supported  under 
FSPL II. The process of revising the decree on deposit insurance will begin in 2005. 
  

d. 

Anti-money Laundering Regime 

59. 
The  Government  recognizes  the  growing  importance  of  the  fight  against  money 
laundering,  and  there  is  a  rising  interest  in  establishing  an  effective  anti-money-laundering 
regime. Of critical importance are measures to (i) enhance awareness of anti-money-laundering 
activities  within  the  Government  and  private  businesses,  (ii)  establish  the  legal  and  regulatory 
basis  for  combating  money  laundering,  and  (iii)  devise  systems  for  reporting  suspicious 
transactions.  SBV  and  MOJ  have  sent  representatives  to  observe  meetings  held  by  the  Asia 
Pacific Group on Money Laundering (APG)5 in the past. Government representatives were also 
present at the 2003 and 2004 APG annual meetings. 
 
60. 
The  process  of  establishing  an  anti-money-laundering  regime  in  Viet  Nam  began  with 
the  drafting  of  an  anti-money-laundering  decree  with  SBV  as  the  lead  agency.  The  draft  was 
presented  for  discussion  among  all  ministries  and  government  agencies  concerned  in  a 
roundtable  discussion  held  28-29  August  2002.  After  official  comments  from  government

internationally  accepted  anti-money 

laundering  standards  as  set  out 

in 

 12 

 

ministries and agencies, and appraisal by MOJ, the draft decree was submitted to the Standing 
Committee of the National Assembly on 21 May 2004, thereby fulfilling a subprogram I second 
tranche release condition. The decree contains the essential elements required for an effective 
anti-money-laundering  regime,  including  provisions  for  (i)  customer  identification  by  financial 
institutions, (ii) reporting of suspicious transactions, (iii) functions of the financial intelligence unit 
and  (iv)  international  cooperation  to  fight  money  laundering.  ADB  will  continue  to  provide 
technical input for establishing the financial intelligence unit, as stipulated in the Decree on Anti-
money Laundering through TA4290-VIE.

62. 
During  FSPL  II—subprogram  I  implementation,  the  insurance  sector  experienced 
impressive  growth,  averaging  over  40%  growth  per  annum  in  total  premiums  earned  during 
2001-2003. As of December 2003, there were 24 licensed insurance companies in Viet Nam: 4 
state-owned  insurers,  7  joint-stock  companies,  7  joint  ventures,  and  6  wholly-foreign-owned 
companies.  Total  capital  of  the  insurance  companies  amounted  to  D1,715  billion  in  2001, 
D1,900  billion  in  2002  and  D2,269  billion  in  2003.  The  total  insurance  premiums  amounted  to 
D4,982 billion in 2001, D6,632 billion in 2002, and D10,192 billion in 2003. Insurance premiums 
for life insurance policies were D2,793 billion in 2001, D4,368 billion in 2002 and D6,317 billion 
in 2003. Insurance premiums for non-life insurance policies were D2,189 billion in 2001, D 2,624 
billion in 2002, and D3,875 billion in 2003.  
 
63. 
At  present  there  are  eight  financial  leasing  companies—five  state-owned,  one  joint 
venture, and two wholly-owned foreign leasing companies—operating in Viet Nam. Total assets 
of the leasing companies amounted to D1,950 billion in 2001, D3,120 billion in 2002 and D4,360 
in  2003.  The  total  amount  of  lease  contracts  outstanding  amounted  to  D1,630  billion  in  2001, 
D2,770  billion in 2002, and D3,980 billion in 2003.  Leasing companies’ high asset growth has 
prompted all leasing companies to apply for an increase in chartered capital in 2004. 

  

 

13 

To  date,  the  money  market  transactions  have  been  limited  to  trade  in  valuable  papers 
64. 
between  SBV  and  credit  institutions  as  a  monetary  policy  tool.  Secondary  market  trading 
volumes  for  valuable  papers  have  been  insignificant.  Trading  between  SBV  and  the  credit 
institutions  through  open  market  operations  amounted  to  a  total  of  D21,184  billion  in  2003. 
Decision 477 issued on 28 April 2004, replacing Decision 516, will require that credit institutions 
report trading volumes of valuable papers in the secondary market as of 1 January 2005. This 
will allow SBV to better track money market transactions between credit institutions. 
 
The  capital  market,  on  the  other  hand,  is  experiencing  steady  expansion.  As  of  May 
65. 
2004, the HCMC STC had 24 listed companies, with total market capitalization of D3,906 billion. 
Also as of May 2004, the total value of government bonds and corporate bonds listed stood at 
D16,472  billion  and  D157.7  billion, respectively.  The  daily  turnover  for  each  trading  session is 
D12.1  billion.  There  are  currently  13  securities  firms  in  Viet  Nam  with  total  capital  of  D605.73 
billion and 1 licensed investment fund with a total value of D300 billion.  
 
66. 
Available data shows that the financial subsectors being supported under FSPL II, with 
the exception of the money market, are experiencing solid growth. Although it is still too early for 
assessments, the program objective to develop alternative channels of financial intermediation 
appears  to  be  on  track.  Performance  of  each  subsector  will  continue  to  be  closely  monitored 
and relevant data compiled throughout FSPL II implementation. 
 
D. 

Conclusion on Implementation of Subprogram I 

67. 
The implementing agencies' commitment to complete FSPL II—subprogram I was visible 
in the steady progress made toward fulfilling all policy actions throughout implementation. Of the 
17  second  tranche  release  conditions,  15  are  fully  met  and  2  substantially  met,  with  ongoing 
compliance.  Quality  of  outputs  under  subprogram  I  has  been  generally  satisfactory.  The 
capacity to implement reforms varied, however, and periodic shortages of qualified staff caused 
delays in the reform agenda. Capacity of implementing agencies is being developed under the 
two  TAs  and  it  is  assessed  that  with  strong  commitment  to  continue  with  the  reform  program, 
the Government is ready to proceed to FSPL II—subprogram II. Moreover, there is momentum 
building in undertaking reform measures within the financial sector components covered under 
FSPL  II  and  continuing  with  FSPL  II––subprogram  II  without  interruption  will  be  important  for 
achieving program objectives. In view of the significant progress made in the implementation of 
the overall Program and the substantial compliance with the second tranche conditions, release 
of the second tranche of the FSPL II––subprogram I is justified. 
 

V. 

FSPL II SUBPROGRAM II—PROPOSED LOAN 

A. 

Progress in Policy Actions under Subprograms II and III 

68. 
The  Government  has  demonstrated  its  commitment  to  reform  by  taking  advanced 
actions in a number of key areas. These are discussed below. Details of the progress with all 
FSPL II—subprogram II and III policy actions are in Appendix 4. 
 

1. 

Insurance Sector  

69. 
FSPL II proposed MOF to develop and apply an early warning system to detect risks of 
failure  at  insurance  companies  by  reviewing  operations  and  financial  positions  (policy  action 
subprogram  II,  A.  4).  With  the  assistance  and  technical  inputs  from  experts  engaged  under 
TA4035-VIE,  the  early  warning  system  was  developed  and  issued  on  27  September  2003  as 

 14 

 

Decision  153:  System  Monitoring  Indicators.  To  build  the  overall  capacity  of  insurance 
professionals,  MOF  was  to  establish  an  insurance  department  in  the  Finance  Institute  (policy 
action subprogram II, A. 6). MOF has combined subdepartments of the Finance Institute into a 
Banking  and  Insurance  Department,  currently  offering  a  4-year  insurance  training  program. 
MOF trainers for the insurance program are being trained with support from AFD.  
 

2. 

Leasing Sector  

FSPL II identified regulatory and administrative gaps to be addressed for developing an 
70. 
enabling  business  environment  for  the  leasing  sector.  A  major  gap  was  that  the  leasing 
companies  were  only  able  to  engage  in  financial  leasing.  FSPL  II  proposed  that  SBV  issue  a 
regulation  allowing  leasing  companies  to  provide  both  finance  and  operating  leases  (policy 
action subprogram II, B. 1). SBV issued a regulation to allow operating leases on 15 June 2004. 
SBV intends to further strengthen the legal framework of the leasing sector by revising Decree 
16, governing the leasing industry, in which operating and financial leases will be both covered 
as the main activities of leasing companies. 
 

3. 

Capital Market 

71. 
In  order  to  foster  the  capital  market,  FSPL  II  supported  the  establishment  of  a  trading 
board  for  SMEs  and  developing  institutional  investors  in  Viet  Nam.  Specifically,  FSPL  II 
proposed that (i) SSC to approve a trading board for SMEs in Hanoi (policy action subprogram II, 
D.  2),  and  (ii)  the  Government  to  issue  the  amended  Decree  48  including  regulations  on 
establishment  of  securities  investment  funds  (policy  action  subprogram  II,  D.  4).  The  policy 
action to approve a trading board for SMEs in Hanoi was also specified as a trigger condition for 
processing  subprogram  II.  Both  policy  conditions  have  been  met.  The  MOF,  on  behalf  of  the 
SSC, issued an implementing circular on 17 June 2004 detailing the operational design of the 
Hanoi STC. So far, SSC has a preliminary list of 10 SMEs that may list on the Hanoi STC. The 
Government  also  issued  Decree  144,  a  revision  of  Decree  48,  on  28  November  2003.  It 
includes  provisions  for  (i)  participation  in  an  investment  fund,  (ii)  form  of  investment  fund,  (iii) 
establishment  of  an  investment  fund,  (iv)  application  documents  and  a  timeframe  for  granting 
licenses  for  establishment  of  an  investment  fund,  (v)  dissolution  of  an  investment  fund,  (vi) 
investment  fund  board,  (vii)  a  custodian  bank,  and  (viii)  operational  principles  of  a  fund 
management company. Subsequently, the SSC licensed Vietnam Securities Investment Fund to 
begin operations in March 2004 (policy action subprogram III, D. 2). The closed-end fund has 
mobilized D300 billion, the ceiling as of 20 May 2004.  
 
72. 
Decree 144 also acknowledges the establishment of a securities association to operate 
on  a  voluntary,  self-regulated,  and  self-funded  basis.  Promoting  and  recognizing  a  securities 
industry  association  is  a  policy  condition  under  FSPL  II  (subprogram  II,  D.  5).  The  Vietnam 
Stock  Exchange  Business  Association  was  established  under  Decision  29/QD-BNV,  dated  11 
June 2003, by the Minister of Home Affairs. The first general meeting of the Securities Business 
Association was held on 17 December 2003. All 14 securities brokers are now members of the 
association. 
 

4. 

Financial Infrastructure 

73. 
FSPL  II  also  proposes  to  strengthen  Vietnam  Accounting  and  Auditing  Association's 
(VAA's)  role  within  the  private  sector,  which  is  constituted  predominantly  of  SMEs.  The 
Enterprise Law of 2000 requires the adoption of the Vietnamese Accounting System, but most 
SMEs  lack  the  capacity  to  adopt  it.  FSPL  II  requires  that  MOF  support  establishment  and

subprogram II, E-1. 5). With the support of MOF, an assistance center has been housed within

than 1,300 SME staff have attended these training courses.

others,  AFC  and  AASC,  are  undergoing 
for

The Government has shown strong commitment to undertaking policy actions agreed to 
75. 
under  FSPL  II.  Throughout  FSPL  II—subprogram  I,  steady  progress  has  been  made  in 
implementing  the  overall  program  and  fulfilling  the  policy  conditions  in  line  with  program 
objectives. However, completing policy measures required significantly more time than originally 
to  understand  concepts  and 
envisioned. 
mechanisms that were new to the country. Furthermore, mandatory consensus building before 
actual  reform  implementation  proved  time-consuming.  Technical  inputs  were  indispensable  in 
enacting rules and regulations such as the anti-money-laundering decree and revised circulars 
on  accounting  systems  for  insurance  companies.  The  TAs  ensured  that  best  practices  were 
incorporated  and  consolidated  throughout  the  consultation  period  to  achieve  the  intended 
results.  
 
Fostering  a  solid  understanding  of  the  underlying  concepts  and  mechanisms  for 
76. 
modernizing the financial system and ensuring consultation with all stakeholders, including the 
private  sector,  are  assessed  as  having  a  long-term  positive  impact  on  the  sustainability  of 
program outputs. Given the experience of FSPL II—subprogram I, and specifically the need for 
consensus building, more time has been allocated to meet specific policy measures for tranche 
releases under subprogram II, allowing time for consultation particularly with the relevant private 
sector stakeholders. 
 
77.  While  progress  was  good  in  some  areas  of  the  Government's  planned  reforms,  others 
confronted  formidable  challenges,  such  as  those  related  to  SOCB  and  SOE  restructuring.  For 
example,  by  mid-2002,  most  interest  rates  had  been  liberalized  and  the  Government's  priority 
shifted  to  developing  the  money  market  by  issuing  short-term  treasury  bills  on  a regular  basis 
and  improving  SOCBs’  treasury  function.  FSPL  II  supports  developing  money  market 
instruments  such  as  certificates  of  deposit  and  short-term  treasury  bills  and  improving  the 
market  structure  by  introducing  money  brokerage  firms  to  penetrate  through  the  segmented 
banking  sector.  However,  SOCBs’  commercial  orientation  must  significantly  improve  for  active 
secondary  trade  on  the  money  market  to  take  place.  While  SOCBs'  operational  and 
organizational  restructuring  is  outside  the  scope  of  FSPL  II,  delays  in  banking  sector  reforms 
were  identified  as  a  risk  factor  at  the  time  of  program  formulation.  This  was  to  be  mitigated 

 16 

 

through  the  comprehensive  reform  package  formulated  with  the  assistance  from  World  Bank 
under its poverty reduction support credit (PRSC). ADB will continue to consult IMF and World 
Bank  on  measures  to  strengthen  SOCBs'  commercial  orientation  and  treasury  function  during 
FSPL II—subprogram II. ADB's participation in PRSC would have the potential of providing an 
effective platform for developing yet closer cooperation with the World Bank and other bilateral 
donors involved in banking sector reforms. 
 
78. 
SOE restructuring has also experienced delays, with a number of implications for FSPL 
II.  The  most  prominent  issue  has  been  the  quantity  and  quality  of  companies  listed  on  the 
HCMC  STC.  FSPL  II—subprogram  II  has  two  policy  measures  under  the  capital  market 
component  for  increasing  the  number  of  listed  state-owned  enterprises.  One  policy  measure 
calls for SCERD, in cooperation with SSC, to issue a list of SOEs that are candidates for listing 
(policy action subprogram II, D. 1). The second policy action requires companies meeting listing 
criteria  to  disclose  the  same  information  as  listed  companies  in  order  to  prevent  regulatory 
arbitrage  (policy  action  subprogram  II,  D.  3).  An  assessment  of  SOE  restructuring  concluded 
that  proposing  policy  actions  to  complement  the  latest  developments  in  SOE  reform  would  be 
more  meaningful.  As  consensus  on  the  broad  framework  on  SOE  restructuring  is established, 
targeting  a  specific  group  of  SOEs  to  move  forward,  and  possibly  to  list,  would  be  more 
relevant.  The  two  FSPL  II—subprogram  II  policy  actions  relating  to  listing  of  SOEs  and 
disclosure of information have therefore been refined (paras. 88-90). 
   
C. 

Refined Policy Framework and Actions for Subprogram II 

79. 
The Government requested to combine FSPL II—subprograms II and III (in accordance 
with paragraph 94 of FSPL II RRP) during the 2004 country programming mission (12-27 April 
2004).  The  request  was  made  on  the  basis  of  (i)  relatively  small  loan  sizes,  and  (ii)  more 
certainty in completing specific policy actions. 
 
FSPL  II—subprograms  II  and  III  are  proposed  to  be  consolidated  into  a  single 
80. 
subprogram  with  three  tranches.  In  formulating  the  subprogram,  all  policy  actions  proposed 
under  the  FSPL  II  cluster  were  discussed  with  the  Government.  Essentially  all  policy  actions 
that  were  proposed  in  subprograms  II  and  III  have  been  maintained.  (For  details  see 
Refinements under Proposed Subprogram II in Appendix 4.)  
 
81. 
Under the insurance component, proposed revisions comprise (i) exclusion of one policy 
action on an approval system for opening new branches and representative offices of insurance 
companies,  (ii)  replacing  one  policy  action  for  strengthening  corporate  governance  with  two 
policy  actions  specifically  addressing  concerns  of  the  current  operations  of  the  insurance 
industry,  (iii)  adding  one  policy  action  on  strengthening  supervision  and  prudential  regulation, 
and (iv) adding a new policy action on enhancing industry professionals. 
 
82. 
Under the capital markets component, a policy action for broadening the capital market 
base and another policy action for establishing a consolidated regulatory framework have been 
refined  to  better  reflect  developments  in  SOE  restructuring  and  progress  in  the  Government's 
plans to upgrade the legal framework of the capital market.  
 
83. 
Under the component for improving the financial infrastructure, minor refinements have 
been  made  for  establishing  the  secured  transactions  systems  and  strengthening  the  deposit 
insurance corporation, taking into account the progress made by the Government and specific 
bottlenecks found during FSPL II—subprogram I implementation. In terms of preventing money 

  

 

17 

laundering, more specificity have been added to the policy action on establishing the financial 
intelligence unit, reflecting the Government's advanced understanding of the requirements. 
 
84. 
A complete set of reforms to be implemented in FSPL II—subprogram II is in the Policy 
Matrix (Appendix 5). Policy actions that have been refined or added to reflect the Government's 
achievements,  the  evolving  policy  environment,  and  lessons  learned  from  subprogram  I 
implementation are discussed in detail below.  
 

1. 

Insurance Sector 

85. 
Policy  actions  under  the  insurance  component  were  revised  to  consider  the  sector’s 
growth,  which  has  given  rise  to  the  need  to  strengthen  corporate  governance  and  prudential 
regulations. The policy action proposed for development and introduction of an approval system 
for  opening  new  branches  and  representative  offices  of  insurance  companies  and  insurance 
brokers (policy action subprogram II, A. 1) was sufficiently covered under the revised Circular 71 
and is excluded from the newly formulated FSPL II—subprogram II.   
 
86. 
To strengthen corporate governance, a policy action requiring MOF to submit a plan to 
the Government to improve corporate governance, including ownership structure of state-owned 
insurance companies and joint stock insurance companies (policy action subprogram III, A. 3), 
is replaced by two policy actions. The two new policy actions address specific concerns of the 
current  operations  within  the  insurance  industry.  The  first  is  the  lack  of  reliability  of  annual 
accounts, and the second is the absence of institutional frameworks to monitor and control risks 
inherent to the sector. The newly formulated FSPL II—subprogram II policy actions proposes to 
enhance  corporate  governance  of  insurance  companies  by  MOF  by  (i)  requiring  insurance 
companies  to  have  the  annual  accounts  cosigned  by  an  MOF  authorized  auditor;  and  (ii) 
recommending that insurance companies adopt compliance manuals and establish compliance 
committees,  audit  committees,  and  risk  management  committees  by  holding  seminars, 
workshops, and publishing reference materials on MOF’s web site. 
 
87. 
To strengthen supervision and prudential regulations, a policy condition has been added 
encouraging MOF to introduce regulations requiring signoff of reserves in the annual accounts 
by  an  actuary  approved  by  MOF.  A  policy  action  mandating  that  at  least  50%  of  MOF’s 
Insurance Department staff complete insurance-related courses at the Finance Institute or other 
MOF-recognized institutes is now included under FSPL II—subprogram II. 
 

2. 

Capital Market 

88. 
Two  policy  actions  under  the  capital  markets  component  have  been  refined  to  ensure 
that concrete actions are taken toward meeting the program objectives of broadening the capital 
market  base  and  establishing  a  consolidated  regulatory  framework.  The  two  original  policy 
actions are (i) the SCERD, in cooperation with SSC, issue a list of SOEs that are candidates for 
listing  (policy  action  subprogram  II,  D.1);  and  (ii)  MPI,  together  with  SSC,  require  joint-stock 
companies  that  meet  listing  requirements  to  disclose  the  same  information  as  the  listed 
companies to the National Business Information Center (policy action subprogram II, D.3).  
 
89. 
SCERD has prepared a list of more than 200 companies with registered capital of more 
than  D10  billion  as  candidates  for  listing,  but  whether  these  companies  will  actually  list  is 
uncertain.  The  Government  has  prepared  concrete  plans  for  SOE  equitization.  However,  the 
option  to  list  must  be  considered  by  the  SOEs  themselves  in  the  process  of  equitization, 
particularly  large  SOEs  with  the  potential  to  benefit  from  listing.  To  make  listing  attractive  for 

 18 

 

SOEs,  the  newly  formulated  FSPL  II—subprogram  II  requires  that  SSC,  in  cooperation  with 
MOF, revise Decree 64 on SOE equitization to provide incentives for equitizing SOEs to list. 
 
90. 
Furthermore,  to  consolidate  the  regulatory  framework  and  surveillance  system,  SSC 
plans to draft a securities and exchange law for submission to the National Assembly in 2007. 
Enactment  of  a  securities  and  exchange  law  is  a  welcome  move  given  the  capital  markets’ 
fragmented legal framework and the limited effectiveness of a decree as a legal basis for capital 
market  operations.  SSC  is  expected  to  be  given  more  concrete  legal  power  to  undertake 
supervision,  surveillance,  and  enforcement  of  laws  over  the  securities  market.  To  support  the 
SSC in this endeavor, FSPL II—subprogram II includes a policy action to draft and submit the 
securities  and  exchange  law  to  the  Government  which  would  include  (i)  corporate  disclosure 
requirements;  and  (ii)  supervisory,  investigation,  surveillance,  and  enforcement  mechanisms. 
Disincentives  for  listing  on  the  HCMC  STC,  such  as  requiring  substantially  more  corporate 
disclosure  than  unlisted  companies,  will  be  addressed  in  a  comprehensive  manner  under  the 
securities and exchange law. 
 

3. 

Financial Infrastructure 

a. 

Secured Transactions System 

91.  MOJ  was  to  continue  implementing  the  registry  of  secured  transactions  in  three  other 
provinces  and  cities  under  central  management  on  the  basis  of  a  centralized,  and  networked 
registration  system.  It  was  also  tasked  with  building  a  national  database  system  for  secured 
transactions  (policy  action  subprogram  II,  E-2.  6).  FSPL  II  also  supports  MOJ  in  submitting  a 
draft law or ordinance on registration of secured transactions to the National Assembly (policy 
action subprogram III, E-2, 2). The Government has determined that an ordinance will be issued 
for secured transactions, incorporating all procedural matters related to registration of secured 
transactions. Rather than continuing with registration system expansion, it is important for MOJ 
to  take  stock  of  all  activities  of  current  registries  to  improve  the  system  and  ensure  that  the 
ordinance  submitted  in  2005  supports  those  improvements.  Accordingly,  the  two  conditions 
were  revised  as  follows:  (i)  MOJ  to  undertake  a  comprehensive  review  on  the  experience  of 
operating registries and list specific measures for increasing the use of the registration system; 
and (ii) MOJ to submit a draft ordinance on registration of secured transactions to the Standing 
Committee of the National Assembly, containing all procedural requirements for registration. 
 

b. 

Deposit Insurance 

92. 
FSPL II also revisits the issue of phasing out people's credit funds from DIV coverage. 
The  original  policy  condition  required  the  Government  to  consider  revising  the  Decree  on 
Deposit  Insurance  to  gradually  remove  people's  credit  funds  from  DIV  coverage  once  the 
system safety fund, which will serve to cover depositors of failed people's credit funds, is fully 
operational  (policy  action  subprogram  III,  E-3.  3).  However,  little  progress  has  been  made  in 
establishing and operationalizing the system safety funds. Both DIV and SBV stressed the need 
to conduct a more detailed and pragmatic study on the different models before proceeding with 
the establishment of the system safety fund. Given the importance of this issue and the need for 
careful planning, the newly formulated FSPL II—subprogram II sequences measures to phase 
out  people's  credit  funds  in  two  steps:  (i)  to  complete  a  feasibility  study  for  determining  the 
appropriate  model  for  depositor  protection  in  people's  credit  funds  (subprogram  II  second 
tranche  release  condition),  and  (ii)  the  Government  to  approve  a  funded  system  for  depositor 
protection in people's credit funds (subprogram II third tranche release condition). 
 

  

 

19 

c. 

Anti-money Laundering  

93. 
Subsequent  to  the  issuance  of  the  Anti-Money  Laundering  Decree,  it  was  agreed  that 
concrete  steps  should  be  taken  to  establish  a  financial  intelligence  unit.  Two  conditions  were 
added  to  strengthen  the  anti-money-laundering  component,  specifically  for  the  purposes  of 
establishing and operationalizing the financial intelligence unit. The newly formulated FSPL II—
subprogram  II  supports  the  Government  in  establishing  and  operationalizing  the  financial 
intelligence unit with adequate staffing and internal procedures. The compliance programs will 
be developed in consultation with the private sector.  
 
94. 
Furthermore,  the  policy  action  to  join  an  international  organization  for  anti-money-
laundering  activities  was  upgraded  to  require  full  membership  rather  than  observer  status. 
Joining APG will help Viet Nam gain recognition from the international community as a country 
with  a  firm  commitment  to  fighting  money  laundering  and  financing  of  terrorism.  Viet  Nam  will 
also benefit from the contacts, information, and training provided through such an organization. 
 
D. 

Subprogram II Loan Amount and Tranches 

95. 
The proposed loan for FSPL II—subprogram II will comprise an ADB loan of $35 million 
equivalent from ADF. Subprogram II will be released in three tranches: (i) $10 million equivalent 
from ADF upon compliance with the first tranche conditions, (ii) $15 million equivalent from ADF 
subject to fulfillment of second tranche release conditions, and (iii) $10 million equivalent from 
ADF  subject  to  completion  of  third  tranche  release  conditions.  The  implementation  period  for 
subprogram II is proposed to be 24 months. The first tranche is expected to be released after 6 
months  from  loan  effectiveness.  Completion  of  policy  actions  for  second  and  third  tranche 
release is expected within 18 and 24 months, respectively, from loan effectiveness. 
 
96. 
AFD has proposed to cofinance €35 million for FSPL II: €23 million for subprogram I and 
€12 million for subprogram II. AFD will disburse subprogram II in tranches simultaneously with 
ADB disbursements, on the same schedule and conditions. The proceeds will be disbursed to a 
special account and will be used to finance costs of projects, which are directly linked to reforms 
in  the  financial  sector,  6  according  to  procedures  defined  between  AFD  and  the  Government. 
The  details  of  the  cofinancing  arrangement  have  been  finalized  under  a  separate  loan 
agreement between the Government and AFD. 
 
E. 

Implementation Arrangement 

97. 
Implementation  arrangements  adopted  for  FSPL  II—subprogram  I  have  been  effective. 
The procedures for procurement and disbursement of funds, and the use of counterpart funds 
for subprogram II, will be the same as for subprogram I. With respect to fiduciary risk, the World 
the  Country  Financial 
Bank  conducted  a  comprehensive  assessment  and  produced 
Accountability  Assessment  (CFAA)  dated  15  October  2001.7  Following  the  CFAA,  the  World 
Bank  has  provided  a  PRSC,  one  aspect  of  which  is  to  finance  a  public  financial  management 

                                                 
6  The projects that have been identified thus far include the establishment of the Hanoi STC, training the insurance 
sector professionals at the Finance Institute, support for future financial intelligence unit, the purchase of equipment 
for  the  transaction  center  for  money  market  operations  at  the  State  Bank  of  Viet  Nam,  and  support  for  the 
implementation of the secured transactions system under the Ministry of Justice.  

7   Country Financial Accountability Assessment indicated that there is a certain degree of fiduciary risk in the use of 
public  resources,  given  that  the  budget  process  is  not  yet  transparent,  public  access  to  government  financial 
information is limited, and effective legislative oversight is not fully in place. 

 20 

 

system.  The  PRSC  is  currently  under  implementation  and  the  Government  is  taking  steps  to 
improve the transparency of the budget process.  
 

1. 

Program Management 

98. 
SBV will continue to be the Executing Agency for FSPL II—subprogram II. SBV, MOF, 
MPI,  MOJ,  SSC,  and  DIV  will  be  the  implementing  agencies.  SBV  will  continue  to  be 
responsible for the overall program implementation, including administration and disbursement 
of loan proceeds, maintenance of accounts, and preparation of semiannual progress reports. 
 
99. 
A program steering committee (PSC) was formed to coordinate program implementation 
among  government  ministries  and  agencies  concerned.  The  PSC  is  chaired  by  the  deputy 
governor  of  SBV  and  comprises  senior  officers,  duly  empowered  to  make  decisions  on 
subprogram II implementation, from ministries and government agencies including SBV, MOF, 
MPI, MOJ, SSC, and DIV. The program implementation and coordination unit has been formed 
within  SBV,  headed  by  a  senior  officer  of  SBV,  and  staffed  with  SBV  officials  with  sufficient 
knowledge and capacity to assist the PSC and ADB. The unit will continue to be responsible for 
day-to-day implementation of subprogram II.  
 

2. 

Monitoring 

100.  ADB, jointly with AFD and in cooperation with SBV, MOF, MPI, MOJ, SSC, and DIV, has 
fielded semiannual reviews to monitor the progress in FSPL II implementation and assess the 
impact on the structure and development of the financial sector. ADB jointly with AFD and the 
implementing agencies will continue to conduct semiannual reviews to ascertain the progress in 
FSPL  II—subprogram  II  implementation  and  in  particular  to  confirm  compliance  with  tranche 
release  conditions.  The  Government,  ADB,  and  AFD  will  continue  to  engage  in  active  policy 
dialogue  on  sector  issues,  reforms,  and  other  measures  and  advice  on  actions  to  maintain 
FSPL II—subprogram II on course.  
 

3. 

Procurement and Disbursement 

In accordance with the simplified disbursement procedures and related requirements for 
101. 
program loans, all goods and services produced and originating in ADB member countries will 
be  procured,  with  due  consideration  to  economy  and  efficiency,  in  accordance  with  standard 
public  procedures  in  Viet  Nam  and  normal  private  sector  commercial  practices  acceptable  to 
ADB.8  Goods  commonly  traded  on  the  international  commodity  markets  will  be  procured  in 
accordance with procedures appropriate to the trade and acceptable to ADB. 
 
102.  The  proceeds  of  the  FSPL  II—subprogram  II  will  be  disbursed  for  a  broad  range  of 
imports, except for a list of ineligible items (Appendix 6). The Borrower will certify that the value 
of  total  imports  minus  (i)  imports  from  nonmember  countries,  (ii)  ineligible  imports,  and  (iii) 
disbursements  made  under  other  official  development  assistance,  is  greater  than  the  amount 
expected  to  be  disbursed  during  the  year.  ADB  reserves  the  right  to audit  the  use  of  the  loan 
proceeds and to verify the accuracy of the Borrower's certification.

Specific Assurances 

VI. 

ASSURANCES 

In  addition  to  the  standard  assurances,  the  Government  has  given  the  following 

103. 
assurances, which are incorporated in the legal documents; 
 

 

The policies adopted and actions taken before the date of the Loan Agreement 
of FSPL II—subprogram II as described in the development policy letter of FSPL 
II will continue to operate. 

The  Government  will  promptly  adopt  the  policies  and  actions  included  in  FSPL 
II—subprogram II, and specified in the development policy letter of FSPL II, and 
will ensure that such policies and actions continue to operate. 

Conditions for Disbursement 

104.  The  disbursement  of  three  tranches  under  FSPL  II—subprogram  II  is  subject  to 
fulfillment  of  specified  first,  second,  and  third  tranche  release  conditions  and  satisfactory 
compliance with the overall program, as set out in the policy matrix (Appendix 5).  
 

VII. 

THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION AND RECOMMENDATION 

105. 
In  view  of  the  substantial  progress  made  in  the  implementation  of  subprogram  I  and 
substantial  compliance  with  each  of  the  17  conditions  for  release  of  the  second  tranche  of 
subprogram I, I, acting in the absence of the President, under the provisions of Article 35.1 of 
the  Articles  of  Agreement  of  ADB,  have  authorized  the  release  of  the  second  tranche  of  the 
Second  Financial  Sector  Program  Loan––subprogram  I.  Accordingly,  in  accordance  with  the 
established  procedure,  the  release  of  the  second  tranche  will  be  effected  not  less  than  10 
working days after the circulation of this report. 
 
106. 
I am also satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of 
ADB  and,  acting  in  the  absence  of  the  President,  under  the  provisions  of  Article  35.1  of  the 
Articles  of  Agreement  of  ADB,  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  in  various 
currencies  equivalent  to  Special  Drawing  Rights  23,766,000  to  the  Socialist  Republic  of  Viet 
Nam for subprogram II of the Financial Sector Program Loan Cluster, from ADB's special funds 
resources with an interest charge at the rate of 1% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% 
per annum thereafter; a term of 24 years, including a grace period of 8 years; and such other 
terms  and  conditions  as  are  substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  the  draft  Loan 
Agreement presented to the Board.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam: 

Financial  Sector  Program  Loan  II  (FSPL  II)  is  expected  to  increase  the  efficiency  of  financial  intermediation  in  Viet 
Nam  by  developing  alternative  financing  channels,  enhancing  the  potential  for  economic  growth  and  job  creation. 
While the benefits will be felt in all sectors of the economy, its initial overall impact will likely be small given the current 
size of the nonbanking subsector. The benefits of FSPL II—including broader access to financial services and a more 
competitive,  diversified  financial  sector  that  reduces  systemic  vulnerabilities—are  expected  to  become  substantive 
with the concomitant growth  of subsectors  such as insurance and leasing. Beneficiaries are expected to include the 
poor  and  near-poor.  A  broader  and  more  balanced  financial  system  will  have  higher  resilience  to  external  shocks, 
which have serious implications for the poor.

The approval procedures have been specified in Circular 71. 
(Article 5 on revisions and amendments of the business license,

simplify the approval system for changes in the operation of 
insurance companies. Revisions to Circular 71 resulted in 
simplified application procedures for insurance licenses, reduced 
time for new product registration for non-life insurance companies 
(from 2 weeks to 3-5 days), and new product approval procedure

and has been submitted to the Minister of Finance for approval. 
The revised circular, Circular 98, was approved by the Minister of

In 2001, there was only one insurance broker: a joint venture with 
the state. There were concerns that this might result in an unfairly 
high volume of insurance policies referred to state-owned 
insurance companies. In December 2001, MOF licensed one joint-
stock insurance broker and in May 2003, MOF issued approval for 
establishment and license for operation to a French insurance 
broker (Gras Savoy Insurance Broker). Two other domestic 
insurance brokers (Dai Viet and Adong) were also given operating 
licenses. MOF intends to approve operation of several other 
insurance brokers to better meet the growing demand for 
insurance. At the same time, efforts are being made to improve 
the quality of insurance agents to protect consumers from fraud, 
as stipulated under Decree 118-2003-ND-CP.

outreach, MOF granted the company a number of preferential 
treatments, including favorable commission rates for agents and 
expanded its scope of operation. Actual impact has thus far been 
limited.

MOF had conducted annual onsite inspection and regular off-site

and MOF revised the draft. Starting July 2003, an Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) consultant under TA4035-VIE provided 
technical inputs into the revised draft procedure to incorporate 
best practices. MOF has undergone a second round of 
consultation with the insurance companies and the procedure was 
issued on 28 September 2004. Off-site surveillance incorporates 
procedures for information gathering, review of insurance 
companies' files, financial and operational calculations of basic 
ratios, financial and other reviews, and preparation of a report. The 
on-site inspection procedures include selection of full-scale or 
partial review, preparation for and arrangement of meetings with 
the insurance company under inspection, review of internal 
control, underwriting procedures, reinsurance procedures and 
contracts, price or premium setting, claims handling, reserving 
process, discussion of results with the insurance company,

The existing framework for accounting system for insurance 
companies consisted of (i) Decree 42 on a Finance Regime for 
Insurers and Insurance Brokers, (ii) Circular 72 on a Financial 
Regime Applicable to Insurers and Insurance Brokers, and (iii) 
Decision 150/1296 System of Accounts for Insurance Business. 
An ADB consultant under TA 4035-VIE closely reviewed the 
existing framework and found gaps that required immediate 
attention. Practices adopted under the framework led to 
substantial underreserving by insurance companies and was 
perceived as a major risk in a market experiencing 40% annual 
growth rate in premiums received. To correct ongoing practices, 
the methodologies for calculating claims reserves of unearned 
premiums, outstanding claims, and incurred-but-not-reported 
claims (IBNR) was aligned to international best practices under the 
revised Circular 72 drafted and submitted to the Minister of 
Finance for issuance. The circular was issued as Circular 99 on 15

The standing committee of the National Assembly adopted the 
new ordinance for administrative violations in July 2002. The draft 
decree for sanctions against administrative violations incorporated 
the required revisions in accordance to the Ordinance and was 
submitted to the Government in January 2003. The decree was 
reviewed by the Government and issued as Decree 118-2003-ND-
CP of the Government on Dealing with Administrative Offences in 
the Insurance Business. The decree includes breaches of 
licensing provisions, unauthorized assignment of insurance 
contracts, unlawful competitive acts, forcing persons to buy 
insurance or to use insurance or reinsurance broking services, 
breaching of mandatory capital security deposit and reserve 
requirements, and breaches of capital investment restrictions and 
solvency requirements. Under the decree, insurance firms may be 
fined up to D20 million for unlawful competitive acts and D5 million 
for compelling persons to buy insurance. Subsequently, the MOF 
issued Circular 3-2004-TT-BTC on 12 April 2004 providing 
guidelines for implementation of Decree 118. The circular provides 
guidelines for jurisdiction to impose penalties, application of 
minimum and maximum levels of penalties, procedure for 
imposition of penalties, and coordination between functional 
bodies for imposition of penalties. 

Since 1999, insurance companies have been conducting internal 
training on actuaries and loss adjusters. In 2002, 20 students 
started attending the 3-year program on actuarial science opened 
in Ho Chi Minh City (HCMC), which comprises 2 years’ university 
training and 1 year’s training overseas. In October 2003, two 
additional classes opened, one in HCMC and the other in Hanoi. 
As of April 2004, there were 17 students completing the first year 
of the program and 15 students preparing for a third year training 
course in Lyon, France to attend the Institute of Financial Science 
and Insurance at Université de Lyon.

SBV’s credit department drafted the regulation on brokerage 
activities, with the assistance of the ADB consultant engaged

market and the role brokers play in it. Subsequent to consultations 
with the private sector, SBV’s credit department finalized the 
regulation in early 2004 and the SBV governor issued the 
regulation on brokerage activities as Decision 315/2004/QD-
NHNN on 7 April 2004. The regulation allows licensed credit 
institutions to apply for licenses to carry out money brokerage 
activities, including borrowing, lending, certificates of deposit, 
foreign exchange, foreign exchange and interest rate swaps, and 
foreign exchange options. Brokerages may not charge fees 
exceeding 0.02% of total transaction value. Money brokers are 
expected to overcome banking sector segmentation and initiate 
transactions among state-owned, joint stock, and foreign-owned 
commercial banks.

Substantially complied with. 

On 25 October 2002, the Government issued Decree 85-2002-ND-
CP to address the discrepancies found between Decrees 165 and 
178. SBV also issued Circular 07-2003-TT-NHNN on Security on 
Loan and Credit on 19 May 2003. The issue of inconsistency 
between Decree 165 on Security Transactions and Decree 178 on 
Security for Loans Obtained from Credit Institutions was mainly on 
the use of single item of property as security for multiple 
obligations. While this was allowed under Decree 165, it was 
prohibited under Decree 178 in accordance to the so-called "one 
lender" rule. Under Article 11 of Decree 178, a single item of 
property could only be used as security for multiple obligations to a 
single credit institution and only in cases where (i) the ownership 
rights with respect to the property had been registered and (ii) the 
value of the security property exceeded the total value of the 
secured obligations. 

Under Decree 85, a single item of property can now be used as 
security for multiple obligations for one or multiple credit institutions 
provided that (i) all secured transactions relating to the single item 
of property are registered at the office for secured transactions, (ii) 
all lenders agree in writing on the appointment of a representative 
to retain the original documentation on the secured property, and 
(iii) the value of the security property exceeds the total value of the 
secured obligations, unless otherwise provided by law. Circular 07 
provides detailed guidelines on the use of a single item of property 
as security for multiple obligations and specifically states that the 
order of priority for payment among credit institutions secured by 
the same single property will be determined in accordance to the 
order in which the secured transactions were registered in the 
secured transactions registry. Article 11 of Decree 85 is now 
consistent with Decree 165.

In July 2002, SBV consulted the National Assembly’s standing 
committee on drafting the anti-money-laundering decree. The 
standing committee approved SBV’s request in November 2002, 
and the prime minister appointed SBV to lead the process. The 
first draft was completed in January 2003 and circulated to 
relevant SBV departments. After consolidating comments, 
stakeholder consultations were undertaken, including with the 
state-owned commercial banks. Substantial technical inputs were 
also provided by an ADB consultant engaged under TA4035-VIE. 
Subsequent to series of redrafting, the fifth draft was tabled for 
discussion in a workshop held on 28-29 August 2003. Following 
interministerial discussions, the eighth and final draft was 
submitted to the standing committee of the National Assembly on 
21 May 2004. The decree is expected to be issued in 2005. 

The draft decree contains the basic elements for initiating a 
functioning anti-money-laundering regime, including (i) customer 
identification by financial institutions, (ii) reporting of suspicious 
transactions by financial institutions, (iii) functions of the financial 
intelligence unit, and (iv) international cooperation in the fight 
against money laundering. SBV began preparations for the 
financial intelligence unit in July 2004.

No.77/2003/ND-CP on the functions, duties, powers, and 
organizational structure of MOF. This decree established 
a number of new agencies, including the Insurance 
Department which was upgraded from a division under 
the Bank and Finance Department. The Insurance 
Department increased its staff and began operation as a 
fully-fledged department on 1 August 2003.  

At present, there is no plan to separate the Insurance 
Department from MOF. However, recognition is growing 
within MOF that substantial capacity building and 
resources would be required to monitor and supervise 
the sector. A proposal to support financial independence 
of the Department by collecting fees from insurance 
companies has the backing of the industry. 

Awaiting supporting documents to review 
compliance 

An ADB consultant engaged under TA4035-VIE drafted 
an early warning system on non-life insurance in October 
2002. MOF received industry feedback and finalized the 
draft for both life and non-life insurance companies. 
Decision No.153/QD-BTD on the System of Insurance 
Business Monitoring Indicators was issued on 22 
September 2003. The system is designed to detect 
insolvency risks of insurance companies as early as 
possible, and to enable prompt action for monitoring and 
resolving such risks. MOF will use the system to 
enhance industry supervision, and the insurance 
companies will apply the system for improved internal 
risk assessment and control.

Some progress made 

The legal framework in Viet Nam sufficiently enables the 
regulator to deal with problem insurance companies. 
MOF has substantive power under the Insurance Law to 
deal with problem insurers. More specifically, Decree 42 
issued on 1 August 2001 provides regulations on 
financial issues of insurers and brokers, including steps 
to deal with problem insurance companies in Article 51. 
Steps include (i) warning; (ii) temporary suspension of 
operations; (iii) restricting the contents, scope, and 
geographical area of operation; and (iv) withdrawal of 
license. The Insurance Department, as industry 
regulator, also has the power to dissolve an insurance 
company. 

The ADB consultant engaged under TA4035-VIE gave 
technical inputs into specific procedures to deal with 
problem insurance companies, including international 
best practices. A draft procedure has been presented to 
MOF and the relevant officials have reviewed the 
proposal. The draft procedure, however, has yet to be 
discussed with the private sector. MOF and the 
Insurance Department recognize the fact that adopting a 
set procedure to deal with problem insurance companies 
as a key supervisory function of the Insurance 
Department would be important. 

Awaiting supporting documents to review 
compliance 

In 2002, MOF combined a few departments of the 
Finance Institute into a Banking and Insurance 
Department. Currently there are around 100 students in 
the 4-year insurance program. Agence Française de 
Développement (AFD) is supporting the training of 
trainers for the insurance program to ensure the quality 
of the programs being offered.
