Circular 71 on Insurance Underwriting issued on 28 
August 2001, provides implementing guidelines for 
Decree 42 dated 1 August 2001. Chapter II of Circular 71 
provides detailed guidelines on registration and approval 
of terms and rate of new products. MOF has consulted 
the private sector to further improve the procedure for 
obtaining approval on new products. The improvements 
are incorporated in the revised Circular 71 issued by the 
Minister of Finance. Streamlining of the procedure is 
expected to considerably reduce the time required in 
obtaining approval of new products for both for life and 
non-life insurance companies.

The plan to phase out the compulsory reinsurance

Good progress made 

"Strategy for the Development of Viet Nam Insurance 
Market from 2003 to 2010" issued as Decision 175-2003-
QD TTG of the Prime Minister on 29 August 2003 
addresses some of the major governance issues in the 
insurance industry. The structure of the state-owned 
insurance companies has been reviewed. Bao Viet, the 
largest state-owned insurance company, engaged in 
both life and non-life insurance business will be 
transformed into a full financial services provider.  

In October 2003, two other state-owned insurers, HCMC 
Insurance Company (Bao Minh) and VINARE have been 
endorsed by the Prime Minister for equitization. Bao 
Minh has undergone equitization and issued shares to 
the public worth D97 billion in July 2004. While the 
Government will remain a major shareholder in Bao 
Minh, the insurer will issue additional shares, with the 
intent to build up its capital and gradually lower the 
Government's stake.

With technical assistance from both International Finance 
Corporation (IFC) and ADB, the regulation was drafted 
and comments from all stakeholders incorporated. The 
regulation was submitted to Governor, SBV on 19 May 
2003. SBV’s legal department objected, saying that since 
Decree 16 does not cover operating leases and should 
not be allowed. However, this was refuted on the basis of 
the provision in Decree 16 that allowed leasing 
companies to engage in activities other than financial 
leasing. After this legal question was resolved, the 
regulation was issued on 15 June 2004.

Some progress made 
The 1st draft law has been produced with inputs from 
consultants engaged under TA4035-VIE. The draft was 
reviewed as part of a reference material by the steering 
committee for drafting the negotiable instruments law, 
established on 2 April 2004. The steering committee 
comprises representatives from SBV, MOF, MOJ, state-
owned commercial banks, the Ministry of Planning and 
Investment, and the Government's Office. There is 
recognition within SBV on the need to enact a 
comprehensive negotiable instruments law and the first 
draft by the steering committee is scheduled for 
completion by end 2004. Although deliberation of the law 
has been included in the schedule of the National 
Assembly during 2002-2007, no specific session has 
been assigned. SBV will request assignment of the 
specific session, but the outcome will depend on the 
assembly’s legislative agenda.  

The SBV governor issued the regulation on brokerage 
activities as Decision 315 on 7 April 2004. The regulation 
allows licensed credit institutions to apply for license in 
money brokerage activities, including borrowing, lending, 
certificates of deposit, foreign exchange, interest rate 
swaps, and foreign exchange swaps and options. Only 
one state-owned commercial bank inquired at SBV about 
the money brokerage business, and there is concern 
about sustainability given the current level of 
transactions. SBV will need to work closely with 
interested parties to make the business financially and 
operationally sustainable.

Some progress made 

In Decision 477 issued on 28 April 2004, which replaced 
Decision 516, SBV stipulates a reporting requirement of 
credit institutions for all borrowing and lending activities 
amongst financial institutions on a daily basis. Money 
market transactions will be better tracked and Decision 
477 is viewed as an improvement over Decision 516. 
However, it still does not require reporting of liquidity 
positions by state-owned commercial banks. Given their 
extensive branch network and the current information 
technology infrastructure, reporting liquidity positions on 
a daily basis is challenging. A phased approach may be 
taken, where reporting of liquidity positions by the major 
branches is required initially. 

On the restriction of the number of nostro accounts, ADB 
consultant reviewed nostro account management at 
state-owned commercial banks and found the current 
number manageable. SBV’s monetary policy department 
has supplied information on the number of nostro 
accounts of four state-owned commercial banks (about 
30 accounts each). In Circular 01/1999/TT-NHNN7, 
which provides guidance on the implementation of 
Decree 63/1998/ND-CP on foreign exchange 
management, credit institutions are required to submit 
application to SBV for opening new nostro accounts. 
Credit institutions granted license to conduct foreign 
exchange activities shall report the opening of new 
foreign currency accounts abroad within 15 days of their 
opening. Banks that have been granted licenses to open 
foreign currency accounts abroad are required to report 
to SBV activities of such accounts on a quarterly basis 
(Official Dispatch 1247/NHNN-QLNH issued on 
November 15, 2002).

Some progress made 

SCERD prepared a list of 2,000 SOEs to be equitized 
during the next 3 years. The Government approved the 
list at the end of 2003. 230 SOEs have been identified as 
having chartered capital above D10 billion, thus meeting 
one qualification for listing. The Government has given 
equitizing SOEs incentives to list on the STC under the 
revised Decree 64 on equitization. The decision to 
equitize and list rests with SOE management.  

SSC received an endorsement from the Office of 
Government in 2002 for the establishment of the Hanoi 
STC. SSC Chairman subsequently issued Decision 
329/QD-UBCK on 17 December 2003 on the functions, 
duties, powers, and organization of Hanoi STC. MOF 
approved the implementing guidelines for the operation 
of the Hanoi STC on 17 June 2004. The potential 
candidates for listing will have registered capital of D5 
billion to D30 billion. Although SSC has identified about 
10 companies as potential candidates, more consultation 
and awareness campaigns with the enterprises are 
needed. SSC, working with local people's committees 
and business associations, will continue to raise the 
profile of Hanoi STC. The official opening of the Hanoi 
STC is scheduled for 2005.

1.  MOF to strengthen Viet Nam 

Good progress made 

 

 

 

 

Several meetings were held between the finance minister 
and the VAA chairman to improve VAA's capacity in 
2002 and 2003. As a result, VAA now has a premise 
refurbished for operation. MOF also provides funds to 
VAA to offer training courses to SMEs, attend meetings 
of international and regional accounting associations, 
hold biannual seminars and workshops to upgrade the 
capacity of chief accountants, and publish the accounting 
review every 2 months. MOF also remains the major 
provider of reference and training materials to VAA. 

A strategy to 2010 for developing the accounting 
profession was prepared by MOF and a section in the 
strategy is devoted to VAA. However no concrete plan 
for developing the VAA as an SRO has been produced. 
MOF, together with VAA, will prepare an SRO plan under 
subprogram II.

MOF has taken steps to equitize several state-owned 
auditing firms and to change the corporate structure of 
VACO, Viet Nam’s largest auditing company: 

(cid:131)  A&C: in Decision 721/QB-BTC of 2 April 2003, the 

value of the state capital in A&C has been calculated 
at D5.045 billion. The firm sold its shares in 
November 2003 and a general shareholders’ 
meeting was held on 25 November 2003 to establish 
the joint-stock company. The equitization was 
completed in the 4th quarter of 2003. 

(cid:131)  AFC: under Decision 53/QB-BTD of 7 January 2003 
and Decision 502/QD-BTC of 12 March 2003, a 
corporate governance restructuring committee has 
been set up and the enterprise is being revalued in 
accordance with Decision No.3395/QD-BTC issued 
on 6 November 2003. 

(cid:131)  VACO: MOF has issued a decision to transform 

VACO into a one-member limited liability company 
under Decision 1927/QD-BTC issued on 30 June 
2003. VACO officially became a one-member limited 
liability company as of 1 January 2004. 

(cid:131)  AASC: the firm has submitted a proposal to the MOF 
for its transformation into a one-member limited 
liability company. MOF issued an official dispatch 
No. 1925/TC-TCCB of 4 March 2003 requesting the 
firm to formulate a corporate governance 
restructuring plan and to transform into one-member 
limited liability company in 2004.

While the owner of VACO will remain the MOF, the firm 
will be operating under the Enterprise Law, a step 
forward toward better governance of the auditing firm. 
Changes in ownership structure of state-owned 
accounting firms are planned to continue in 2005. 

Decree 105 on Independent Auditing, replacing Decree 7 
of 1994, was issued on 30 March 2004. Decree 105 bans 
establishment of any new state-owned auditing 
companies and requires all currently state-owned 
auditing companies and joint stock companies operating 
under the Enterprise Law to be converted into 
partnerships, private companies, or foreign-invested 
firms.

to submit the Ordinance to the National Assembly as 
early as the end of 2004.
